newsitem.title: MEXICO: Salinas y Rocha says debt pact ready soon.
newsitem.headline: Salinas y Rocha says debt pact ready soon.

text.p: Mexico's Grupo Salinas y Rocha on Monday said it would sign a final debt-restructuring agreement with creditor banks within 15 days.

The troubled retailer said through a statement in the Official Gazette that its shareholders on July 24 had approved a preliminary debt-restructuring plan signed earlier with banks, paving the way for a final agreement.
The agreement calls for the company to reduce its share capital from 345.86 million pesos to 20 million pesos, absorbing the difference as financial losses during previous quarters.
Of some 4.4 billion pesos in debt, the company will securitize about 54 percent, restructure some 21 percent and pay off the rest with real-estate assets.
Banks will own the bulk of shares but will leave management control to the company, according to the plan.
The company's creditor banks are Grupo Financiero Serfin, Banco Santander Mexicano, Banca Confia and Grupo Financiero Bancomer.
Salinas y Rocha was hard hit by the 1994-95 peso devaluation, which caused sales to plummet and the cost of its dollar debt to skyrocket.
